slides.title: Studying 2
slides.subtitle: Techniques that make study stick
bullets: Practical, evidence-aligned study habits
Short talk with an actionable template
slides.speaker_line: Welcome — this deck will show simple, proven swaps to make studying actually work.

slides.title: The Problem
bullets: Most people “study,” but don’t learn.
Re-reading notes feels productive, but it doesn’t stick
Highlighting makes you familiar, not fluent
Real learning happens when your brain has to retrieve and apply
slides.speaker_line: If studying feels easy, it’s probably not working.

slides.title: The 3 Rules of Effective Study
bullets: Active recall: force your brain to pull information out
Spaced repetition: revisit over time, not in one big block
Deliberate practice: target what you get wrong, not what you already know
slides.speaker_line: These three are the difference between ‘I saw it’ and ‘I can do it.’

slides.title: Active Recall (What to Do)
bullets: Blurting: close notes → write everything you remember → check gaps
Practice questions: exam-style problems, not summaries
Teach-back: explain the concept like you’re tutoring someone
Quick example: Instead of “read the chapter,” do: “Answer 10 questions, then mark and fix errors.”
slides.speaker_line: Swap passive review for retrieval practice: make the brain reach.

slides.title: Spacing + Interleaving (How to Schedule)
bullets: Spacing: shorter sessions over multiple days beats cramming
Suggested rhythm: Day 0: learn → Day 1: recall → Day 3: recall again → Day 7: mixed practice
Interleaving: mix topics; don’t do one topic for 3 hours straight
It feels harder in the moment → that difficulty predicts better long-term learning
slides.speaker_line: Schedule difficulty: make retrieval slightly effortful and spaced.

slides.title: The Feedback Loop (How to Improve Fast)
bullets: After every session ask: What did I get wrong? Why?
Look for repeating patterns of error; those define your plan
Rule: Your mistakes are your study plan
Spend ~70% of time on weak areas, 30% on review
slides.speaker_line: Use errors as the roadmap: focus most time on what you actually get wrong.

slides.title: A Simple 45-Min Study Template
bullets: 0–5 min: set a clear, specific goal (what you will do)
5–25 min: active recall / practice questions
25–35 min: mark answers + update an error log
35–45 min: re-attempt wrong questions + schedule next review
slides.speaker_line: No fancy motivation needed — just a system.

slides.title: Closing (20 seconds)
bullets: Effective studying isn’t about time. It’s about technique.
If you do only one change: swap re-reading for retrieval (practice questions + recall), then space it out.
slides.speaker_line: Do the hard part: retrieve, correct, and repeat. That’s how learning sticks.
